property.name: text
property.value:
Modeling counter machines in data flow -- Part 1 -------------------------------------------------------------
An integer n is represented by a sequence of n false tokens, followed by a terminating true token. For example: 0 -> true 1 -> false true 2 -> false false true etc. This model shows how to implement increment/decrement by 1 and test-to-zero in dataflow. Also word-level select and switch.

property.name: text
property.value: Authors: Edward A. Lee and Stavros Tripakis

property.name: text
property.value: NOTE: The model gives an exception but that's OK.

property.name: text
property.value: Takes n and returns n+1, encoded as boolean token streams. For example: true -> false true false true -> false false true etc.

property.name: text
property.value: Takes n and returns n-1, if n>0, and 0 otherwise. Both input and output are encoded as boolean token streams. For example: true -> true false true -> true false false true -> false true etc.

property.name: text
property.value: It is easy to specify the behavior as a finite-state machine with 2 states: true, false, and a boolean input in. Initially state = true. Transition function: next state = in; Output function: if state = true then if in = true then out = true; else /* in = false */ out = nothing; /* no token output in this case */ else /* state = false */ out = in;

property.name: text
property.value: State update (transition) function: next state = in

property.name: text
property.value: Signal "tmp" is an "almost correct" output. It's wrong when state = true and in = false. In this case, we should not output anything. The switch actor does that: it throws away the value of tmp in that case.

property.name: text
property.value: Takes n and returns true, if n=0, and false otherwise. Both input and output are encoded as boolean token streams. For example: true -> true false true -> false false false true -> false etc. Notice that all the input stream is consumed.

property.name: text
property.value: It is easy to specify the behavior as a finite-state machine with 2 states: true, false, and a boolean input in. Initially state = true. Transition function: next state = in; Output function: if state = true then if in = true then out = true; else /* in = false */ out = nothing; /* no token output in this case */ else /* state = false */ if in = true then out = false; else out = nothing; /* no token output in this case */

property.name: text
property.value: State update (transition) function: next state = in

property.name: text
property.value: Signal "tmp" is an "almost correct" output. It's wrong when state = true and in = false. In this case, we should not output anything. The switch actor does that: it throws away the value of tmp in that case.

property.name: text
property.value: Implements a select but trueInput and falseInput are streams, instead of single tokens. For every true/false token consumed at the select input port, it consumes the entire corresponding stream at trueInput or falseInput port, and produces it at the output. Both trueInput and falseInput streams must follow the encoding "n falses followed by 1 true" of integer n>=0.

property.name: text
property.value: Implements a select but input is a stream, instead of a single token. For every true/false token consumed at the select input port, it consumes the entire input stream, and produces it at the corresponding output port. The stream must follow the encoding "n falses followed by 1 true" of integer n>=0.

property.name: text
property.value: Takes n and returns n+1, encoded as boolean token streams. For example: true -> false true false true -> false false true etc.

property.name: text
property.value: Takes n and returns n+1, encoded as boolean token streams. For example: true -> false true false true -> false false true etc.
